I solved that by simply tucking one of the many towels provided in-between the door and its frame and slept like a child on a large soft cosy bed.If you don't know what to do in the evenings, you'll have an HD TV set in your room, so you can watch local TV for free. There is a couple of hotel channels as well, broadcasting video reports about different places and activities around the island. I found that useful and followed a couple of their recommendations.Unfortunately, as I was travelling alone, I could not qualify for a free breakfast program. If you will go with someone, you will be eligible. But still, there are a lot of places to eat around, from McDonalds and Subways to nice restaurants, so that is not a problem. As for me, I was fine with my morning coffee alone; after that I used to buy a bottle of water or a vitamin beverage and go around the island (don't forget to have water with you on Hawaii at all times, you can start dehydrating even before you notice).Waikiki Malia does not have a pool, but neighbouring OHANA hotels have, and you will be welcome there free of charge. If you will have some time during your last day of stay, they will let you take a shower even after you checked-out, so don't hesitate to have your last dip in the ocean. And they will also store your bags for you before you go.I have not checked it myself, but the OHANA key card should let you ride at least the pink line tourist trolley for free.

It was a special trip for me & my husband and wanted to be extra special. Before I start saying anything about the hotel services, I would like to thank the help desk with all my heart that was so helpful & prompt. The hotel is centrally located and not too far away from the Waikiki Beach which is a big tourist attraction. Trolleys are pretty accessible, the stop is right outside the entrance. We took a meal package with Ohana Waikiki Malia, and I must say that the selection of restaurants was above my expectation specially Kani Ka Pilla Grille. I had to mention this since I share my name with the restaurant ;)I personally feel that the housekeeping service should be excellent, and this hotel definitely stood up to my expectation.All in all our stay with this hotel was good.

stay was wonderful, staff made us feel at home when we first walked in from our long trip. room was nice, pretty parital ocean view, (some buildings blocked full view.) house keeping gal was sweet and always greeted us with a cheerful hello. walking distance to EVERYTHING! staff always made it a point TO MAKE SURE I GOT RIGHT DIRECTIONS... MAHALO! looking forward to return and bring back the family and friends and YES i recommend it for a comfortable stay. HAWK and LADYFree High Speed Internet needs some work. connection was on and off...

This was the first time we stayed in this hotel but, have had friends stay at Ohanas before so I booked it and was very skeptical about the price but, it turned out to be a wonderful stay the front desk staff and cleaning lady was very nice. Our room was clean and spacious and what I think was a CA king size bed. Very roomy for us. The only problem is the parking garage it seemed to be an afterthought for the building. It's very tight and if you have anything over an economy size car good luck trying to park or go up or down the steep ramps. You do have to pay for parking as well but that seems to be in most of the hotels on the island. The location is great just a block or two from the International Market and on the beach is just one street over. Everything else in Waikiki is in walking distance to this hotel because it is centrally located.We look forward to our next stay oh and there is an IHOP located on the bottom of the building.
The desk manager, clerks , maids, all were number one in our books.
The front desk staff was very friendly and helpful as were the other staff members. The room was always immaculate upon returning at the end of each day. Close to evrything we needed.

This hotel look good on the out side but the hidden inside is not what I thought it to be. The hotel staff is qutie rude and not understanding at all. When booking the hotel I was not told that if you don't pay for the hotel with a credit card you will now have to pay the fee of $250.00 up front and the cost of the room with it. The bill was totalling 500.00 for two nights. When I told the hotel manager about this bill I was told " thats just way it goes." and before I could get me card and say I cantpay this bill he canceled My reservation. I had to walk with my stuff (a bunch of bags) to the ohana west and that hotel saved the day. I would not even let my dog stay in that malia hotel.

My husband and I had a great time staying at Ohana Malia hotel.Rooms are newly renovated and very clean.Bathroom was spotless.As far as we a concern hotel has a great location;we will stay there again.Cant wait to book our next holiday.

The first night I got for free by using some hotel points from staying at other hotels on the main land. The other nights were in the same hotel but diferent room. It was nice also. The staff were very friendly and wanted to help as much as possible when a family member hurt herself.

I was extremely worried about the hotel based on some of the reviews on this website. However, when I got there I found the staff to be very nice, the room was clean, and the location was great. Everything was within walking distance. There are air conditioners in the bedroom and main room. The kitchenette made it so easy to have breakfast in our room and save on costs. Yes, the singles in the main also acted as couches, but this was not a problem at all as the coverings meant no one actually sat on the bed sheets or pillows. The only downfall was the parking...the entrance and exits were extremely difficult to negotiate for anything bigger than a small car.

We traveled to Hawaii with our two young kids choosing to go to Waikiki because of the many activities and attractions for our family. Once arriving we were overly delighted in the hotel we chose for it's FANTASTIC location, cleanliness and curteous employees. The hotel was only minutes from the beach, so we could walk there freely. We were right in the center of many restaurants, shops and the main walking streets. And for families with kids their was a McDonald's next door. Excellent value without the high cost of on the beach expense.The hotel staff and management were always very helpful in accomodating room selection, when possible, late check out, towel check out, etc, directed by the gracious General Manager Nora Weatherwax and So'otaga Tana (Front Office Manager) and all other members. Thank You for a wonderful stay!

The ohana chains in hawaii are cheap but comfortable. They are clean and have great customer service employees. My stay was short and sweet and I wish it lasted longer. The room that I stayed in was recently renovated and it looked fabulous!

I've stayed at hotels in the Ohana chain many times, and have always found them to be a good value for the price paid. No, they are not 5-star hotels - so don't go with the expectation that they are. But they are a modestly priced chain, with clean, comfortable rooms, and friendly, competent staff.The Waikiki Malia is in a good, central location in Waikiki - just one block north of popular Kalakaua Ave, and about 4-5 blocks from the beach. It was a pleasant 10-15 minute stroll from the hotel to the beach every day (shorter or longer, depending on how many times you veer off into a store to shop along the way :) The rooms are a nice size, and comfortably furnished. Ours had a mini-fridge which was great to store snacks and drinks, and we had a small lanai for fresh air. Granted, the lanai was small - but it was nice to step out there now and then to check the weather and see the traces of sunrise or sunset. A big bonus about the room was the free wired internet. Internet access is one of my top amenities when I travel, so it was much appreciated. Another nice amenity is the access to the Waikiki Trolley pink line, which we used to take a trip to the Ala Moana shopping center, but you could hop on/off at multiple stops around Waikiki. You can get a free ride just by showing your Ohana room key. The front desk staff was extremely pleasant and helpful, as they always are in the Ohana chain. We also enjoyed the "welcome gift" we received, which was a small drawstring backpack that we used every day when going to the beach. All in all, the Ohana chain can't be beat. When I go to Hawaii, I'm there to soak up the sun and relax on the beach, as well as shop a little bit. I'm rarely in my hotel room, so I don't need alot of frills and an expensive room, which is why Ohana is perfect for me.Mahalo, Ohana!

The Title said it all. I think it's in a great location, easy access, restaurant available inhouse and around. I would definetly go back. No pool, but you can go to the other associate pools....I kind of like that....get to see and use the other facility. I get to see more of the area.One peeve and I don't understand it....it just doesn't make any sense. I reserved two rooms, signed for them, is responsible for the rooms and will be paying for them, then was told to assign my guests to each room....all of this and guess what? I was not allowed to have a key for the second room. This was the situation: my wife and I planned to spend a night with family (mostly children), a total of 8 people. Myself and the children, one being 19 years of age were at the hotel earlier then the others (6 of us) and we had to jam all in one room until the other two arrived (adults). I will talk to the manager about this and get a clear answer. I just didn't want to waste my time, at the time.

I would stay there again. I decided to extend my vacation and wanted to stay in Waikiki and the rate that I got online met my budget and also when I called to confirm the staff was very professtional and at the same time displaying the spirit of Aloha which I appreicated. Before arriving the staff did let me know that there was contriction going on and that they usally started later in the day to allow guest to get some sleep. Then staff that had greet us were very pleasant and also the staff that cleaned our room. I highly recommend Ohana Malia if your traveling on a budget. The only downfall is parking I think $18 is alot for 24-hours but at the same time I understand the need I just think that $18 is very high I could havede spent that at the bar or IHOP which directly downstairs of the hotel. But overall good experience.

Stayed at the Ohana Malia. The staff were very pleasant, the room was excellent for the price. The daily room service was excellent. I would definately stay there again. It is right in the middle of it all in Waikiki, close to all the shops and restaurants, buses right outside. Complimentry unlimited rides on the pink trolley. About a 5 minute walk to the beach. If you are on a budget, you can't get better than this. The only thing I didn't like is I took the breakfast package which included breakfast each morning at the IHOP restaurant next door. After the third day I cancelled the breakfast deal as that IHOP is the most disgusting place I've ever been too. The staff was as rude as you could get, none of them knew what was going on and the breakfast we received was worse than lousy crap. The rules of the breakfast changed each day and it was nothing but arguing with the waiting staff, even the manage had no idea what was going on with the hotel breakfast. I would definately recommend staying at the Ohana Malia but don't take the IHOP breakfast package. You'll be sorry if you do.

A girlfriend and I took our granddaughters to Oahu with Northwest World Vacations. We each had a room with a living room, kitchenette and bedroom for seven nights and air from Minneapolis for $950 each. Yes, the rooms are a little worn, but the air conditioning was just fine and it was nice to have the kitchenette. We did have an occasional noise from a motorcycle or truck but no construction noise. We were just 3 blocks from the beach or the International Market Place. We were two blocks from the great Waikiki restaurants. My husband and I have stayed at many 5 star hotels but for this trip it was perfect.

The staff is very nice and helpful, but the hotel at least the room we stayed in was run down dump. The trip was booked through American Airlines Vacations which really let me down which suprised me because American is such a great airline. Our room was awful we were promised a one bedroom suite with 3 beds (one bedroom and a room with two twin beds) and it included one bed in a small room with no tv and another small room with a barely working tv with two uncomfortable day beds. The paint was chipping, doors were broken, balcony had all the comfort of a parking lot, doors and items were covered with rust, dirty disgusting capeting, moldy smell, beddings that looked and smelled 40 years old and a shower you didn't want to use. The hotel is a rundown mess. The only people that might it enjoy it our college students with no money and just want a place to sleep at night and don't care about being in a dump because they are drunk, which is the only condition you can endure this hotel. It was torture. Even the halls and elevator were run down and ugly.The manager did try and set us up at another hotel but it would have cost us extra which we had not budgeted for, and we thought at $240 a night we were going to get something not fantastic but at least descent and not a flop house.I always like to read the reviews on Trip Advisor first, but I thought I could trust AA Vacations I was wrong, very wrong. And of course AA Vacations when we arrived and complained they were unable to help because the office was not open and almost a month later have not responded to my complaint about my trip. So you would want to double and triple check any AA Vacation hotels, it would probably be better to go with Priceline, which has never disappointed me and always surveys me afterwards to find out how my experience was, you can probably guess AA Vacations does not provide surveys about your experience and after you pay your money they are pretty much done with you. As I mentioned this is sad because my experience with American as an airline has been great, but as far as hotels check Trip Advisor and use Priceline. It's extra sad because the trip was a Christmas present for my mother who always wanted to go to Hawaii and truly AA Vacations drop the ball and even after finding out they did such a poor job and has done nothing.

I don't recommend this hotel for people looking for a relaxing and quiet vacation. I intended to stay there for 2 weeks, but had to check out after a week. The hotel was okay for the price, but the noise was just unbearable. There was construction on the rooms going on during the day, and at night, groups of people would come back at midnight and later. They would walk across the hallway and knock on each other's doors and talk in the hallway. It didn't help when they went into the rooms because the walls were paper thin. I did ask to be moved after two nights of not being able to sleep. But that room was good for only two nights, since another group of people moved in. Then on Fri and Sat night people would be drinking in the next room with the patio door open. It made it sound like they were actually in your room and having a party. If you plan to not be in your room during the day and party at night, then it's a good deal. If you plan to have a relaxing vacation, then I would not recommend this hotel.

Helpful Ohana Malia Hotel Accomodating to disabled visitor. I recently returned from a weeks stay and wanted to make aware to disabled visitors the courtesy and flexibility this hotel offered. I'm totally disabled, in a power wheelchair and needed medical equipment in a hotel that would accommodate me. I had a hospital bed, patient lift, ventilator and other medical equipment delivered by Apria, Pearl City, thank you Frannie! The management was generous and considerate to my needs. Knowing I needed adequate space to move around, the manager enthusiastically upgraded my room. The handicapped accessed bathroom with roll in shower was extra large and very clean. Anything I needed, was brought right away. The staff were excellent. I have stayed at other handicapped hotels in Waikiki, and this was my fourth stay here. For me, there isn't a better hotel as accomodating as the Ohana Malia for disabled visitors. Any handicapped visitor to Oahu would be happy to know of such a nice place that exibits the essence of aloha! Kudos Nora Waxman, Manager Ohana Malia. MahaloConi Foster

First off, the staff was very nice. Okay, now on to business.Hotel is under construction and I was not told this on the website or when booking reservation by phone. This means loud banging during the day and a balcony door that doesn't open.There is no internet access in the rooms. Do not be fooled when you click on this box as a requirement and this hotel comes up. You can only get wifi in the lobby. In the rooms there is nothing. NOTHING.

I loved this hotel!!! It was clean and the staff was nice. It is a 5 minutes walk from the beach and the international market place. By booking our stay at this hotel we got free surf lessons and access to the pool and jacuzzi of the hotel next door.

My husband and I stayed at this hotel for two nights whilst on our way back home to Australia from the Big Island of Hawaii, because we couldn't get a flight out on the date we wanted so the travel agent gave us two days in Honolulu and booked us into this hotel.The hotel is very old and very outdated and the rooms are very dark, dingy and unclean - I really didn't even want to have a shower barefoot - that's how clean it was! Carpet was disgusting and the coverlet/bedspread on the bed was pretty tattered and faded.The only thing we did kind of like about this place was its location - it wasn't very far from Waikiki Beach and the shopping/market areas.As much as we enjoyed our trip and the few days we had in Honolulu, we really couldn't wait to get out of this place!

Even though the pool and other facilities was not functional during our stay, the friendliness and accommodating spirit of the staff more than made up for it. It just goes to show you that service is of the essence when making or breaking a hotel/vacation experience. Everyone was very nice and courteous, but Troy the bellhop was especially great. His friendliness was a true embodiment of the aloha spirit.For example, my departure flight was at midnight. Because the hotel staff was nice enough to let me shower and tidy up at night in a clean "hospitality suite" even after I checked out, I was able to spend the day at the beach without having to worry about boarding a long flight in a sandy and grimy condition. The hotel staff also did many other little things to make the stay very convenient and pleasant. And all this for a budget price!I will recommend this hotel to friends and family, and will stay here again the next time I come to Oahu.

I've stayed at the Ohana Waikiki Malia several times in the past year. Though some of the rooms need to be updated (old carpet, tired bedding) I've found it to be clean and good value for the money.Reading some of the other reviews puzzled me. The lobby is clean and modern, not at all institutional, as another reviewer has said. The staff has always been helpful and polite.What I like most about the hotel is the willingness to give extended checkout at a reasonable price -- $10 per hour. My stays in Honolulu are stopovers on long trips. I generally check in about 4 a.m., and check out at 4 p.m. Other Waikiki hotels want entire night's fee for a checkout time this late, instead of the $40 I pay to the Malia.I think it is good value for the money.

We stayed for one night, for a mini-Waikiki vacation. The rooms were clean, the staff pleasant, and although there is no pool here, the desk staff directed us to sister hotels 3 blocks away where we could use the pool. They give you a great coupon book upon checkin, and we used some of them. The AC was excellent--in fact, we were too cold and had to turn it off! There is a bit of traffic noise from the street below if you get a room without a view--but this is the middle of Waikiki after all. And the view of the lights of Waikiki that we could see from our room was great. Close to shops, restaurants, and clubs. We left the car parked and took advantage of the baggage courtesy check when we wanted to stay past checkout time. The only thing they could improve would be to give better directions to the parking garage. The Kuhio St. entrance is very steep and narrow; we left some rubber! Lewers is better. Very safe hotel, friendly staff, nice, clean place, would definitely stay again.

We stayed here for 8 nights, and had a wonderful time.Hotel staff were very friendly and helpful, rooms were very clean, and serviced daily. Our room had a King Size Bed, Iron, Ironing Board, Hairdryer and Coffee Machine.........No kettle though, so if you prefer a cup of tea in the morning then take a heating element or kettle along.The hotel provides the use of beach towels which you just drop off in the foyer on return to the hotel.Our friends had a room on the 12th floor, and again, no problems. Their room had two double beds, and we all agreed our rooms and bedding were clean and comfortable.The odour that people seem to complain about is probably the slight musty smell in the corridor, which would only bother you if you were sleeping in the corridor I guess. The rooms were fine. I have a fear of lifts, and can assure all, that although there was a slight wait for the lift to come to the floor sometimes, once inside they moved quickly and quietly.I have some photos of the rooms but unfortunately am unable to upload them, but again, rest assured the rooms are very clean and comfortable.The four of us arrived before 10:00am, and we were allowed to access our rooms immediately.Would have no hesitation in recommending this hotel and its staff. Had a wonderful time, and it is a pleasant walking distance to the beach. No pool on site but you can access the pools of two other Ohana hotels a short walk away if you like.

Stayed at Ohana Malia on Kuhio Ave for our last night, $99 rate. Previous to this, we were at the Ohana Waikiki Beachcomber on Kalakaua for 3 nights/$129. Friendly and proffessional staff. Stale old rooms, 70's decor, very dated and in need of and update. For the rate it was decent and clean...comfort wise, I preferred the Beachcomber. Liked the pay internet service in the lobby since we didn't bring our laptop. If you don't use up your paid minutes you can write down an access code and use the unused time later on. Dined at the IHOP next door, fast friendly service. Bus stop for Diamond Head was across the street and free trolley depot behind the hotel. Convenient location.Okay if you are on a budget or spend most of the time at the beach. We opted for late check out since our flight wasn't until 9pm. $10/hour charge for each hour after the normal noon checkout time. However, frontdesk forgot to notify housekeeping of our 6pm departure and we got a knock on the door at noon from the housekeeper.Would stay again if on a tight budget.

My family of five stayed at the Waikiki Malia for a soccer tournament. We requested a crib for our infant and to have a room near the laundry room because I was planning on washing soccer uniforms every night. Both requests were fufilled. Another plus was that we were located near an ice machine which is very convenient for us to fill our coolers for the long day at the soccer fields. The parking stalls were also in very close proximity to our rooms. This made it convenient for us to lug the soccer and baby gear to our van each morning. We stayed in a suite. The master bedroom was roomy enough to place the baby's crib right in next to me. The separate room allowed my sons to sleep through the night without being awakened by their sister's crying in the middle of the night. I requested two twin beds for the living room. This was a big plus because I didn't have to listen to the boys fight all night long, "he's touching me..he's hogging the blankets" The rooms were clean. The beds were okay but I am used to sleeping on Tempurpedic mattresses at home. IHOP is right downstairs. No need to find a restaurant in Waikiki and then find parking or have to pay for parking. This was very convenient.Parking was a bit scary at times. The parking garage ramps are steep and narrow. We have officially named this the soccer hotel. It is perfect for families traveling for tournaments. I would not stay here for vacation but we will definitely stay here again for our future tournaments. I prefer the Doubletree or Ala Moana for vacations but the Malia is perfect for our next soccer tournament.

I didn't think this hotel would be that good because of all the negative reviews that it received but in reality, this hotel is great! It is an older building and the furniture is olden, but its still clean and very cozy. We stayed in the building that had 8 floors, not the 1000 unit one and it was very quiet. The lanai had a nice view from the 5th floor and at night when you shut the window and curtains, there isn't any noise. Housekeeping washed our dishes everyday and changed the bedding every 2 days, but when we called them they changed it everyday. & they even give pool towels, just ask.When we had to leave, the front desk even booked a taxi for us.Next year, we're defiantly coming here again!

I can't say anything was really nice about this Hotel. The rooms are dark and very old, they are not at all sound proof and the road noise is extremely loud. The lifts are very old and quite scary. There is no swimming pool and no internet connection in the rooms, you have to go to the lobby to connect.Certainly do not recommend it.

Very poor Hotel by Waikiki standards.Given that this is a very popular holiday location I was expecting a much better hotel experience.Firstly it was hard to find, I hired a car to get around and drove past the hotel a number of times before I found the entrance. I had to squeeze the car into the very small car park.The staff were not rude but really didn't go out of there way to be over helpful.The rooms were very old fitting wise. It was clean but run down. I didn't feel safe on the balcony and felt that the tv was very small given the size of the room. I was woken up a number of times by people coming and going from other rooms on the floor and by the light that comes in under the door.The location was OK, a bit of a walk to the beach.I was expecting a lot better for the money I spent, but I see this as a learning experience and won't book through a travel agent again!

We booked a package from Australia and only had a choice of 3 hotels in Waikiki - I chose this one because it was out of the main beach area - which from previous visits I knew was very busy. To be honest after reading the reviews here I was dreading it - people had mentioned stains, dirty carpets and bed bugs!!However I was really pleased when I arrived - we got there early (10am) and was told the room was ready - we were on the 12th floor - the room was large and airy with a huge window (the balcony is very small) and I have absolutely no complaints and would stay there again without doubt.The hotel is very central - the free pink tram has a terminus in the DFS building behind and you are within walking distance of everywhere. I only had a couple of encounters with staff downstairs and they could not have been more helpful. All in all a very good quality hotel.

Stayed 5 nts. Hotel and room was very clean and spacious. The staff helpful and courteous. Great security. Location excellent. Great deal for the money. Would stay there again and recommend to anyone.

We booked this hotel through United Vacations. We travel to Hawaii nearly every year. This was the first time we have stayed at this hotel, though we have stayed at an Ohana brand hotel before.Our room--1516--had lots of problems. The air conditioner in that room is about to die, as evidenced by the constant loud rattle of the fan. We didn't use it much because it was so noisy, and it had a bad odor. The carpet is very worn and stained. The refrigerator door is hanging by one hinge and must be lifted to get it to close. We also didn't use the dresser drawers because they were disgusting. When we notified the front desk, we were told the brown, smeared stains were "paint." It looked quite a bit like something else, and the drawers were musty-smelling. The entire room was dusty. My parents were staying in the room next door, which had an OK carpet, a nice refrigerator, a working and quiet air conditioner, but still musty in the dresser drawers.If you like to sit on the lanai, stay elsewhere. The Malia's lanais are so tiny you can't even get a chair out there. The Malia is on Kuhio, a busy, noisy street. If noise bothers you and you choose to stay here, bring earplugs or buy some at the ABC Store across the street. The Malia is a long walk to the beach and has no pool. You can use the pool at the Ohana Maile Skycourt, Ohana West or Ohana East, though these hotels are as far away as the beach and their pools close early (8 or 9 PM depending on the hotel). We didn't even take the time to look at the available pools.We used the laundry facilities at the Malia. The washers are fine. It costs 2 dollars to wash. The dryers cost $1.50 to dry, but the inefficient dry cycle is only about 25 minutes, so it actually cost me $4.50 to dry a half load of lightweight cotton clothes. The laundry is on the 5th floor of a very dark, deserted garage that is open to the public. Kind of scary.The good things: Front desk staff was fine. For most of our stay the housekeeping staff did a good job and was pleasant. (We did have one fellow for a day or two who did a really lousy job.) Free daily coffee for the in-room coffee maker and free daily newspaper was much appreciated. Free rides on the Pink Trolley is a useful perk. Rooms are large for Waikiki, with a real bathtub in the bathroom instead of just a shower. I might stay here again IF the management would fix the air conditioner, do something about the really gross carpet, replace the refrigerator, paint the inside of those drawers, and keep them clean with an occasional bleach and water scrubbing.

This hotel was a huge disappointment. It was very dirty (the carpets, furniture, bathroom, walls) and looked like there was mold growing on the ceiling and around the ventilation ducts. Housekeeping had to come and change our bed sheets because the ones on the bed were stained and disgusting (GROSS!!!). The staff is not very friendly and it's just a dirty hotel overall. Look elsewhere- or spend a little more for a nicer hotel

This is a good choice for those traveling on a budget during tourist season. The location is perfect - a short 2 block walk to the beach and International Market Square. It is on the pink line trolley system which gets you to Ala Moana shopping. The hotel has a deal with the trolley and guests travel it free of charge. The city buses also run right past the hotel. There is not a pool at this location (remember beach being 2 blocks away) but you are free to use other Ohana facilities - all within a 4 block walk. IHOP has recently opened adjacent to the hotel so breakfast was a breeze. The rooms were clean. Each room has a coffee maker, small refrigerator and room safe. Various toiletries are supplied as well. The bed was a bit on the hard side and the pillows left something to be desired - but this is a budget hotel too!

I never thought that I could stay in a better place. It says 3 star, but it defenatly deserves a 5. The pictures don't do it justice. The staff was amazing, the rooms were clean, the pool was glicening. I normally only stay in 5 star properties, and my travel agent told me about his one. She said that she was leary because of the reviews, but she stayed there, and wont stay anywhere else. So I took her word for it, and stayed there, and boy am I glad that I did. When I checked in, there was a small problem with the room, they had double booked it. I was really upset and ready to raise heck, but before I could say a word, the refunded me for half of my stay AND bumped me up to a suite. I think I am going to take all of my vacations in Honolulu, and always stay here. I could go on all day. I know that some reviews are less than a 5, but I don't know where they came from. Maybe the hotel saw the reviews and were proactive about getting the problems fixed. It was just magnificant!!

Was a little nervous about staying at this budget-priced hotel for 6 nights with my wife and 14-year-old daughter, but overall it was pretty decent. The room was on the small side, but clean and fresh, with fairly comfortable beds. The six dresser drawers were pretty nasty, however; only one was clean enough to use. The bathroom was a nice size, with good water pressure and constant hot water. Nice central air conditioning (although the cover plate for the controls was missing; instead, it was labeled with a sharpie: Hi, Lo, Off). Very small lani (balcony) without any furniture (only 1 small chair would fit anyway). The biggest drawback are the very thin walls and windows. Heard all the noises on the street from our 11th floor room (facing Kuhio Ave.). Even worse, you can hear every sound from neighboring rooms, from toilets flushing to alarms going off. Not to mention guests socializing in the hallway all night long and the endless slamming of doors. Most of the guests seem to be either young party people or military, at least over the 4th of July holiday. The location is great, maybe a 10-minute walk to the beach (if you go thru the Waikiki Sheraton). City buses and the Hilo Hattie trolley are right outside the door; other trolleys are right around the corner at the DFS Galleria. Extra charges: parking garage was $15 a day, $3 a day to use the room's safe, $2 if you use the supplied bag of kona coffee. There was a free newspaper outside your door each morning. The front desk provides you with beach towels (which are actually just the same small bath towels that are in the bathrooms). There is a newly opened IHOP restaurant adjacent to the hotel, recently converted from the old Malia Cafe. Nice, new decor, very crowded for weekend breakfast. Overall, not a bad place to stay when you can't afford those expensive beachfront resorts.

My husband and I stayed at the Ohana Waikiki Malia for one night because we arrived in to Honolulu too late to catch an interisland flight to the Big Island. I knew it would be pretty low-end but figured for one night it wouldn't be that bad. It was pretty bad. The hotel has a bizaare institution feel to it from the lobby to the elevators to the halls. The room was dirty, the curtains were stained from smoke (even though it was a non smoking room), the entire room had a sickly sweet smoke smell to it, and the ceiling was stained. The carpet was thin and stained and not something you wanted to walk on in our bare feet. The bed sheets were stained. The air conditioner sounded like a jet engine taking off making it impossible to keep on while trying to sleep. The noise from the street was terrible, and the other guests in the hotel seemed to all get home at 3am and need to run up and down the halls and slam doors to announce that. The only reason I gave this hotel two stars instead of one was because of the suprisingly clean and renovated bathroom, I almost wanted to sleep in there. As far as budget hotels in Waikiki go, there has GOT to be better options than the Ohana Waikiki Malia. Spend the extra $30 per night and stay at the Ohana East, they don't even compare for cleanliness.

Nice rooms in a covenient Waikiki location. Paid $89 for each of 2 nights through their website. The room was not musty like many Waikiki hotels. The room was nice and clean and included a small balcony. We had a comfortable king-sized bed. The bathroom was standard for a budget priced hotel. A free newspaper was provided in the morning. There wasn't really any restaurant except for breakfast which we never tried. Extra charges for parking ($15), room safe ($3) and coffee. Please be warned that the parking garage had the steepest and narrowest ramps I have ever seen. All in all, a good value in the heart of Waikiki.

Stayed at the Ohana Malia from 17-23 March 2006. We booked through our Travel Agent in Australia and were promised approx 3 star accommodation. And i would agree that this is what we received. I went with my Aunt and we had twin double beds. We stayed on the 17th floor. The room was clean and tidy, with Air Conditioning and TV. All worked well. The bath tub was good but the shower water pressure was very weak. They came in and made up the beds every day and put in clean towels which was good. There was a bar fridge but no kettle for hot water. They only had some kind of coffee maker (but you are charged for the coffee). The staff were friendly and helpful. They have an information desk for maps, day trips etc, and they can do bookings for you. We went to the Society of Seven dinner show which was quite good value (very energetic and entertaining), but probably more suited for people over 50-60 years of age. We were able to book the return airport bus ($9 US) from our hotel conceirge which was handy.Overall i was pleased with the cleanliness of the hotel, it's not absolutely flash but it would be very suitable for clean family accommodation.

We were traveling on a budget. Our initial reservations were for the Ohana Waikiki Surf, which is right across the street, but we got moved to the Malia. The location is very good, and the staff is very friendly. I found all the people I encountered in Oahu to be extremely friendly.Now to the complaints. We didn't have hot water two of the 4 mornings we were there. The parking structure is steep and narrow ($15/day). Rooms were small, and our keys kept failing. We had to go to the front desk to re-activate them on more than one occasion.

My husband and I stayed here 7 nights. This was our 2nd trip to Oahu and we just wanted a clean comfortable hotel. When we arrived to the hotel I was pleased with the location. We were close to restaurants, the beach and The International Market place. Our room was clean and service was good. Breakfest in the hotel restaurant was good, but dinner was not good at all.Our room had two double beds with a small lani The lighting near the closet was not very good. The hotel/condos accross from my room were under construction, so when I wanted to change clothes I had to close the drapes or go in the bathroom to change. However the bathroom did have a full size bathtub, with good water pressure, and plenty of hot water. Bathroom was very clean. We were glad the bus stop was very close to the hotel, that was convenient for us.Regarding tours: we booked 2 tours with the hotel tour desk, both tours were really good and the lady was very nice.We had a pleasant stay at this hotel and would stay here again, it is clean and is in a good location, not a beautiful hotel but comfortable and is a good value hotel. We learned from our first trip to Oahu that we did not really spend alot of time in our room except to sleep and shower.

Clean rooms, excellent location (main reason why I keep staying there) and great price for Honolulu.Stayed at the Malia for a second time Feb 4-10 2006. Nice location and good rooms for a bsic hotel. The Malia has all the basic needs and was perfect for what I wanted. I've been to Oahu 6 times now and have stayed here 2 of my last 3 visits (Ohana Tower last time. Torn down now. Lewers st. construction).  The Malia doesn't have a pool or barbeques or many of the other extras that I never seem to use anyway. Just a nice basic hotel with clean rooms, nice bathrooms and a great location. Located on Kuhio (one of the 2 main roads parrallel to the beach) and lewers st. A block or 2 to the International Market Place and Duke's lane on Kuhio. 3 long blocks to the beach. Buses are accross the street and so is the free trolley to Hilo Hattie (nice ride but don't spend much there). If you really want to use a pool, you can stroll about a block and a half to the Ohana Islander and use there's. I never bother. They give you free beach towels at the counter so don't bother packing any. Just ask on your way to the beach and return them after. Nice clean beach towels every day. Very handy. Coin laundry on the 5th floor. Also very handy. Lookout on the roof with a tennis court. If you want a nice clean room at a great location I would recommend the Ohana Wakiki Malia. Side note - The Outrigger Catamaran is great. Been on it a few times. If you get Big Kahuna dollars (on check in), it is a great way to spend them. The Ali Kaii dinner cruise is also great but buy it at Affordable Tours on Seaside st (one street over). They are $22 cheaper, per person, than the tour desk at the Malia. Great dinner cruise. The Zoo is great too. Breakfast at the Shore Bird is nice too. Been to Honolulu a fair bit and can answer some questions if you e-mail me - Sittingduck26@hotm ail.com .

I stayed 10 nights at this hotel (Dec. 12-23rd) 2005. The staff was really nice and helpful, we got a smoking room at first and asked to change, and it was no problem. They even moved the luggage for us. It is clean and well maintained hotel. The location is great. You are 2 blocks from Waikiki Beach and the market. The city bus passes just in front of the hotel where you are 10 mins away from the main shopping centre. This hotel is perfect for low budget traveler like me, being a student; you want quality at a reasonable price. The hotel restaurant on the other hand is kind a dirty, the ceiling was leaking in the middle of the dining room... Not sure its all that clean! And the food wasn’t the best. Anyway, there are tons of great restaurant around the hotel. This little bar/restaurant called Tsunami does great breakfast for only 2.99$! And the servers are really nice.Overall, I highly recommend this hotel.

We stayed at the Ohana Waikiki Malia from the 24th of December through to the 31st of December. After reading several of the reviews about this hotel I was very skeptical about this property. What makes things worse is that I work in the Travel Industry as a marketing co-ordinator I know that flashy pictures and fancy words can fool many. However we were pleasently surprised about how well this hotel measured up. When we checked in we requested to upgrade to the one bedroom suite, and was advised that it would only cost an additional US25 per night plus tax. This was very reasonable and decided to upgrade. We were placed on the 9th floor (top floor), with a nice view of the city. The layout of the suite consists of a lounge room with two single beds made up as day beds and then the main bedroom, it also has a small kitchenette to prepare meals. The large balcony makes is perfect to sit there and enjoy the city and the mountains in the background. The decor was very nice and these rooms had just been recently renovated. The hotel has two wings the Luana Wing Tower where all the suites are located and the Malia Tower wing where all the standard and city view rooms are located.The hotel has a cafe located off the lobby and has buffet breakfast from US7.50 per person. Overall this hotel has exceed all of our expectations and we will be staying here again. As someone who works in the industry I feel the standard is quite good, it's not the Ritz but for the price you pay it's well worth it.

I stayed here for 4 nights in a room on the 14th floor. The room was fairly large and the bathroom was nice enough, and it was all very clean and felt safe. The walls are kind of thin though - when I was lying on my bed I could hear the people next door in the bathroom.They're doing major renovations on the hotel/condos across the road, and my room had a "view" of the construction site/workers so i had to keep my curtains closed most of the time - only a problem for even-numbered rooms, other side of the hotel would be fine. The "lanai" is teeny-tiny (can just barely fit one chair on it and really not even suitable for drying washing). I don't care that there's no swimming pool (it's Waikiki, i'd rather go to the beach!). However, that also means there's no place where you can have a shower or get changed if you have a late flight (I had a 10-hour flight leaving around midnight, and felt really crusty cos i couldn't have a shower after spending the day snorkelling - just had a cold-water rinse at the beach). there were some people from the UK complaining about the same thing so it's not just me. Apparently if it's not fully booked they can open up a regular room for people to shower etc, but the day i was leaving the hotel was full (so no late checkouts either). This would put me off staying there again - all the other hotels i've stayed at in Waikiki have had a "hospitality room" or a gym for people to shower/get changed in before a late departure.

My wife and i stayed at the Malia for 7 nights at the start of november 05, with not one problem to be had.Stayed on the 17th floor and the only noise was the cop cars sirens at night but not that often, (once every three nights). I asked other tourists from other hotels and they said the same thing. Hotel had everything but a pool, great little cafe for breakfast and dinner, a tourist counter was a great help with our sight-seeing, and a really good concierge service. Would really recommend to a couple with only shopping in mind or a family on a budget, because you can use the pools from the other Ohana hotels which is what we did and it was great to talk to other tourists outside your hotel. Location is excellent, with everything close, and public transport stop at the door. Summing it up Good value for money for everything you need.

recently stayed there for 5 nights . as a budget hotel u get what u pay 4 so u can read the other reviews but 2 points i have to add.1) the malia cafe lets the hotel down. the food is the same every morning (buffet) and the staff and kitchen are noisy and distinctly unprofessional (e.g. talking about what shifts to work next week in front of the guests and chastising one another)2) i ordered a movie and the sound was so bad it was unwatchable. ok no big deal as i just called up to cancel it straight away. however when checking out i noticed it was still on the bill and asked them to remove it, when the deskstaff started complaing that it was a hassle to change the bill and why should i bother as it was only 1 movie ($9 ). in addition he was visibly annoyed and amongst other signs of irritation dropped the pen on the desk in order for me to sign the ammendment and told me how i should be greatful for his 'generosity' . maybe im missing something but their movie service didnt work properly and nor did their staff as i had clearly cancelled it over the phone 5 mins in to the movie. who was wasting whos time?? if u want budget stay here, but i hope u have a more pleasant stay than i did!

We had a family reunion and wanted a clean and basic/inexpensive hotel. The price is ok and the hotel room was as expected... BASIC.However, The most irritating part about this hotel was the parking Garage. Spent $17/day. and I cringed everytime we had to get out of the garage and park back the car every night. Parking Garage is narrow and small. We had rented a SUV and a compact car and had no idea how the garage would be. Both cars had a hard time parking in the narrow and steep drive way. Surely ok if you don't care about scratching, denting or damagin your car and others... .

We only stayed here one night because that's all that they had open (we didn't have place to say until we got there - we live dangerously). We only paid $89 for the night, so that may cloud my better judgement here. The room and hotel were very basic. The view that we had wasn't really much of a view at all. The tennis court and observation/sun deck on the roof were great and offered amazing views of Waikiki. If you get this hotel for around $100 and don't mind a hotel that isn't the cleanest or the nicest, stay here.

I recently spent a few nights at the Ohana Malia with my mom and while the rooms were okay, the staff was what made the hotel memorable. On our second to last night we were subject to a group of outrageous, hormonal teenagers running throughout our floor. Thankfully we were heading out to dinner, but stopped by main counter to let them know our concern. They understood our concern and told us that we should notify them immediately of any problems that may occur. We also asked simple things as directions to different parts of the island, where the locals eat, etc. and each time they were amazingly helpful. For those of you curious about the rooms, the room we stayed in had a double bed in the bedroom and twin beds that doubled as sofas in the living room. The bathrooms were nice, spacious and clean. The location of the hotel is just a few blocks from the beach and right by all the Waikiki shopping destinations. Ala Moana shopping center is also within a 5 minute driving distance.

We stayed at the Ohana Malia for a week and enjoyed our stay. Although booked originally into a room facing the street, upon asking, we were moved across the hall to an ocean view. Very nice place for the price, good location to most attractions, and access to beach, couple of blocks away. No pool but that is across the street at the next Ohana facility. Always friendly staff, interesting mix of people in the hotel. I'd recommend it for the value minded traveller.

We stayed for 6 nights at the end of March 2005. The 1 Bedroom Suite we had worked great for the 4 of us in our party, as we needed 4 beds. The room was cleaned each day and staff were all very nice. Parking garage was very hard to navigate the first couple of times but got used to it. Would have been nice to be on an upper floor(we were on the 2nd floor) as noise from the parking garage and street were loud early in the morning. Overall this hotel was fine and worked perfect as everything we wanted was within easy walking distance. Would definitely consider it again. Great bargain for the money.

awful!i felt like i couldn't touch anything.the plumbing was smelly, the water didn't go down the pipes fast enough so you showered with all the water up to your calves.the queues were terrible, not enough staff.the reception being open air meant that I saw rats running around under the sofa near my anklesnoisythe lifts - crikey - rubbish - had to wait far too long - not acceptable.just too large, too many people and not enough facilitiesYUCK!

i just returned on friday from Hawaii and had a lot of stuff go wrong, by far my worst trip and most expensive, definatley never going back. Highly suggest a different place, but if your totally set on going to hawaii this hotel was alright. The hotel people were the most polite people we met there, although we had bad luck so i don't know if that's a compliment, i had a parrott guy start screaming at me as i walked away, and i swear i was very polite turning him down. if you didn't give what they considered a appropriate tip they got nasty and everyone wanted a tip.  the room was clean, the pillows nice and fluffy. whenever we asked the cleaing lady for a towel she would give us 3. the front desk staff were always polite. we had ocean view (a joke, don't let them talk you into paying extra) but they upgraded us for free sinply because i asked nicely. the fans on the mall below us were loud, but i live in the city so that didn't bother me, it's constant, and started sounding like the ocean after a few days (to me anyway). our bathtub started making werid noises the day we checked out, i don't know if that was them cleaning the pipes or relating to the construction work. our last day we didn't leave for the airport until 8pm, they had a nice clean, locked bathroom they let us use to get cleaned up and change for our trip home.

I was in Honolulu for 7 days, primarily on business. My needs were pretty basic and the Malia was a good fit for that situation. No frills, just the basics. I only had one remotely negative experience, the first room I was given was really grungy despite the fact that housekeeping had cleaned it. Walls were yellowed with cigarette smoke and the carpet was so stained I'd be hesitant to walk barefoot. I called the front desk to inquire about another room and they were very accommodating. They relocated me to a newer part of the hotel and the room was immaculate. Despite that first hiccup my stay at the Malia was fine. The hotel was quiet which surprised me being that my new room was located right near the elevator. The staff was very friendly and helpful and the hotel is centrally located so everything I needed was well within walking distance. The thing that impressed me the most though was, after accidentally leaving an expensive item behind in my hotel room, I called to see if they would mail it to me. To be honest I didn't think Id ever see it again when in fact it arrived in the mail today. To me thats indicative of the best kind of customer service.

Arrived off a long flight at midnight with a prepaid voucher for 5 nights in a 1 bedroom suite, night clerk said they didn't have a booking for us but put us in a standard triple room. Next morning they said their reservations centre had declined the wholesalers request as they didn't have 1 b/r suite availabe for the Chirstmas period but could provide one. Changed over to 1 b/r suite, that afternoon front desk rang and said we couldn't have it, would have to change back to standard room overlooking street. Front desk staff not helpful, wouldn't accept prepaid travel voucher, had to pay with our credit card. Rooms overlooking street are noisy, the bedding smelt musty, waited as long as 10 minutes for lift to arrive. Certainly wouldn't stay here again or recommend it to anyone

We stayed in the Ohana Waikiki Malia for 10 days in October 2003. The location was convenient to everything in Waikiki. The staff was helpful and friendly. The room was very clean, except for the A/C vent was very, very dirty upon our arrival. We asked it to be cleaned, and it was within the hour. The parking garage, however, will not accomodate much of a car. We drove an Intrepid, very carefully in and out. Anything bigger, and we would not have made it at all! The restaurant is fine if you want the breakfast buffet. But I would not recommend wasting your money eating there. Poor service is the main problem with that. Overall, it was a nice hotel that we would consider revisiting if there is no availability at the Hale Koa.

When you travel do you like to have an inviting, comfortable place to return every evening? Do you like taking a shower without getting scalded everytime someone in a nearby room flushes the toilet? Does a musty oder bother you? Do you like to watch even a little TV, lets say the morning/evening news and weather on an all color TV, not just in a blue or green tint? I wasn't sure what about our week-long stay was not perfect in Paradise - how could we not be having the time of our lives no matter what hotel we we're staying in? I realized it was the uninviting room we had to return to every evening. O'hana hotels are old and tired. If you want to truly enjoy your entire vacation, spend more money and don't stay at an O'hana.

This hotel is excellent! The reception staff were very helpful (especially at finding a Taco Bell) and friendly.Make sure you park on the sidewalk before checking in (you cant park in the car park). The carpark is very steep and tight for big american cars but I managed so its fine.The rooms were big and clean, bright and our bathroom was really clean, new and nice. We had a balcony too.Might want to ask for a high up floor as the road (Lewers) can get quite busy during the day/early evening. Great location 5 minutes to Waikiki beach but away from the main Aloha noise.Go enjoy - Superb hotel.

We have just returned from the Ohana Waikiki Malia (20th July 2004) and as we arrived I thought it looked a little scruffy. Reception staff are polite but on been shown to our room we found it to be very, very basic. The room was not double glazed so you could hear the traffic, which as you are on a main road with road works going on was not pleasant. They start work on the road at 6 a.m each day. We were told this will go on for another year at least. The cafe in the lobby is of poor standard and not overly clean we felt. You pay 3$ for the safe and 2$ for using the coffee each day. The bathroom is quite small and the shower kept changing temperature while been used! We had the use of a courtesy room on our departure day. This was spacious and very pleasant and we just wish we had been blessed with this room instead of our "pokey little room". We will not return to this hotel but would go back to Hawaii.

My family of four went to Hawaii April 2004 we stayed for 9 days. We had a Standard room, which fit us just fine. Very clean and the maids were very respectable. The price was GREAT! The location was the BEST! We were at the Beach in minutes and the International Market was right up the street (Great Shopping). The trollies and buses were always available for transporting. The Zoo was a nice stroll down Kuhio. There was food eateries everywhere and McDonald's was next door (super for the kids); they serve pineapple with every meal (yummy). We had only one complaint, the parking area was very tight, when driving in the lot patience is a must. We are returning to Hawaii March 2005 and will stay at the Ohana Waikiki Maila again.

By the time we checked it was almost 5 in the afternoon. Parking was terrible and the ramp very steep. Only certain elevators go to certain floors. The room we got looked right into the other hotel and we could see what people were doing with or without the lights off. That meant we had to keep our drapes closed. We went down to change rooms. The other side of the hotel only had smoking left. I even offered to pay extra for a suite but once again only smoking rooms. We finally went back to the original room. The first night was okay but the second was a different story. The room across the hall had 30 people in it and they were singing really loudly late at night. I called the front desk several times with nothing changing. I even went out in the hall to see what room and the security guard was there was told him to listen and get them out. It still did no good and once again I called the front desk and told them if they did not do anything I would call the police. By the time it was 1 in the morning we were so tired we fell asleep to the noise. The rude people across the hall were up at 6 the next morning being loud once again. The hotel staff was very rude, this would never be a place to ever stay again. After having spending two nights in the waikiki beachcomber, this place was awful.

Stayed in the Waikiki Malia early January, 2004. Made the reservations directly at the Ohana website, so paid a bit more than if I had used expedia or a discount service. Room was nice, clean but the balcony was very small. No place to sit out and relax. Overall, a nice hotel with a decent location.

The front desk staff was really friendly, and personable. Parking lot was a bit tight, and tough to drive through, my husband and I got back to the hotel late and had to search for parking, luckily there was ONE spot available. Our room was small, and had a bad moldy/musty smell, it kept me awake most of the night. I'm sure there were better rooms, but we really arent complainers (in person that is, lol). The location is great, right in the middle of Waikiki. In all, the hotel was "alright", it's worth it if your booking on a budget, I've seen a lot worst.

We stayed in the property for 5 nights back in May, 2003. We love it. The location is very convenient. ABC store is right at the corner across the street, so is the bus stop. It takes about 10-minute walk to the beach. The hotel is very nice and quiet when compared to its other sister hotels. Room is clean and has a small refrigerator. The staff is very helpful with directions and other needs. We will love to go back and stay there.

The hotel was clean, the staff was very nice, the room was very nice. We had a two room suite, for 4 people. The room was not overly large, but was large enough. It was reasonably quiet. We were on the 6th floor. The restaurant was good, not excellent, but good. We ate one breakfast and one dinner there. The nice thing is that you can go across the street and use the pool and hot tub at the other Ohana facility and they have an activities desk there as well. The gift shop prices were reasonable. I would definitely stay here again.
